title: Typeface used for National Geographic's new 'Found' blog
content:
National Geographic has a new blog showcasing forgotten imagery,  
it also features a rather lovely italic serif for its masthead.

Initially, I thought it was a Barnbrook face due to the seated italic U, I was wrong.

Anybody have an idea as to which typeface they've used here?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042im_/http:/typophile.com/files/found-logo3_5870.png)
author: WolfC4ke

comments.content:
Barnbrook is a very good guess. But I suspect it's a one-off using multiple fonts. For one thing the weights are a bit imbalanced (which however happens a lot these days with so much junky free stuff out there).

hhp

None really convincing. Some alternatives even you're probably after the real deal: [Tiepolo](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/tiepolo), [Stockmar](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nonpareille/stockmar), [Andralis](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/neufville/andralis-nd), [Lapture](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/justanotherfoundry/lapture), [Cartier Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/cartier-book) and [Hawkhurst](http://web.archive.org/web/20131016222042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/hawkhurst)
